raw_results.scenario_label: Process_Auditor case testing 13h delay in surgery for a 6yo male with supracondylar fracture.

errors: signals:Missing must_find_signals: presented to the emergency department on Saturday at 20:00, the delay from injury to surgery was approximately 13 hours...

engine_output.raw_input: A 6-year-old male presented to the emergency department on Saturday at 20:00 after falling off a swing. Upon examination, he was noted to have a Gartland type III supracondylar humerus fracture on the left side with a pink, pulseless hand. Neurovascular assessment revealed no movement in the fingers, and the AIN motor exam was not able to be performed due to the absence of finger flexion. The patient was kept under observation, and surgery was scheduled for Sunday at 09:00. The delay from injury to surgery was approximately 13 hours. There were no signs of compartment syndrome documented during the assessment, and the surgical team was notified promptly about the neurovascular status. The family expressed concern about the long wait for surgical intervention.
engine_output.summary: A 6-year-old male presented with a Gartland type III supracondylar humerus fracture and a pink, pulseless hand after a fall. Surgery was scheduled for Sunday at 09:00, resulting in a delay of approximately 13 hours from injury to intervention.

errors: signals:Missing must_find_signals: presented to the emergency department on Sunday at 15:30, the delay was due to preoperative clearance processes...

engine_output.raw_input: A 7-year-old female presented to the emergency department on Sunday at 15:30 after sustaining a supracondylar humerus fracture from a skateboard accident. Clinical evaluation revealed an AIN palsy with an inability to perform the 'OK' sign. Neurovascular assessment showed a warm, pink hand with palpable pulses. The surgery was performed at 18:00, resulting in a 2.5-hour delay. The surgical team documented that the delay was due to preoperative clearance processes. There were no signs of compartment syndrome noted during the evaluation, and the patient was stable throughout her time in the ED.
engine_output.summary: A 7-year-old female presented with a supracondylar humerus fracture and AIN palsy after a skateboard accident. Surgery was performed at 18:00, resulting in a 2.5-hour delay due to preoperative clearance processes.

The surgery was scheduled for Saturday at 11:00, resulting in an 18-hour delay. The surgical team indicated that the delay was due to OR availability and the need for further imaging. There were no signs of compartment syndrome documented, although the patient's extremity was closely monitored throughout his stay.

engine_output.raw_input: A 9-year-old female presented to the emergency department on Saturday at 14:00 after a bicycle crash resulting in a right supracondylar humerus fracture. On examination, she exhibited signs of compartment syndrome, including severe pain and tense swelling. The neurovascular assessment revealed diminished sensation and a white, cold hand. Surgery was performed at 16:00, indicating a 2-hour delay. The surgical notes specified the urgency due to compartment syndrome. The patient was closely monitored, and there were no signs of additional complications recorded during her stay.

engine_output.raw_input: A 6-year-old male presented to the emergency department after running into a wall, resulting in a Gartland type III supracondylar humerus fracture. Upon evaluation at 11:00 on Friday, his left hand was observed to be pink but pulseless. Immediate neurovascular assessment revealed no radial or ulnar pulse. He was taken for surgery at 23:00, which resulted in a 12-hour delay. Despite timely intervention post-surgery, the risk of vascular compromise was noted, raising concerns for potential complications. The surgical team documented the findings and emphasized the need for close monitoring.

raw_results.scenario_label: Documentation_Gap case examining inconsistencies in clinical notes for an 8-year-old female with AIN palsy post-fracture.

errors: signals:Missing must_find_signals: swing set collapsed on her...

engine_output.raw_input: An 8-year-old female was brought to the hospital after suffering a Gartland type II supracondylar humerus fracture when a swing set collapsed on her. She arrived at 14:00 on Saturday and was assessed for AIN palsy; however, conflicting notes indicated 'AIN intact' in one section and 'mild weakness in thumb opposition' in another. Surgery was performed at 18:00, leading to a 4-hour delay. Post-operative notes failed to clarify the extent of nerve involvement. The family was advised on follow-up care and potential rehabilitation needs for motor function.
engine_output.summary: An 8-year-old female sustained a Gartland type II supracondylar humerus fracture due to a swing set collapse. She arrived at 14:00 and underwent surgery at 18:00, resulting in a 4-hour delay, with unclear documentation regarding nerve involvement.

errors: signals:Missing must_find_signals: surgery was delayed until 06:00...

engine_output.raw_input: A 5-year-old male presented to the emergency room at 21:00 on Sunday after falling from a height while playing at home, resulting in a Gartland type III supracondylar humerus fracture. Upon examination, the patient displayed early signs of compartment syndrome, including severe pain and swelling. Surgery was delayed until 06:00 on Monday, resulting in a 9-hour wait for intervention. The surgical team documented the critical nature of the situation, outlining the urgency of addressing the potential for permanent damage. Post-operative notes indicated that the patient was monitored closely for any complications.
engine_output.summary: A 5-year-old male sustained a Gartland type III supracondylar humerus fracture after a fall, with surgery delayed for 9 hours due to the critical nature of his condition, including early signs of compartment syndrome.

raw_results.scenario_label: Borderline 17.5h time-to-OR, pink pulseless hand, correctly managed overnight (Process_Auditor)

errors: signals:Missing must_find_signals: presented to the emergency department at 10:00 PM, surgery was scheduled for 03:30 AM the following day...

engine_output.raw_input: A 7-year-old male presented to the emergency department at 10:00 PM following a fall from a tree, resulting in a left supracondylar humerus fracture. Upon arrival, a neurovascular assessment revealed a pink pulseless hand with intact capillary refill but diminished radial pulse. The orthopedic team was notified, and the decision was made to monitor overnight due to the stable condition. Surgery was scheduled for 03:30 AM the following day. Pre-operative assessments were conducted, including an anterior interosseous nerve (AIN) motor exam which showed an 'OK sign' but no other deficits. The patient was taken to the operating room at 03:30 AM the next day, and the fracture was successfully reduced and pinned. No signs of compartment syndrome were noted during the post-op recovery.
engine_output.summary: A 7-year-old male sustained a left supracondylar humerus fracture after a fall from a tree, presenting with a pink pulseless hand and diminished radial pulse. Surgery was delayed until 03:30 AM the following day for overnight monitoring despite stable condition.

raw_results.scenario_label: White, cold hand at arrival, delayed reduction with bad outcome (Safety_Signal + Preventability_Detective)

errors: signals:Missing must_find_signals: white, cold hand at arrival, absent radial pulse...

engine_output.raw_input: An 8-year-old female was brought to the emergency department at 09:30 PM after falling off her bike, resulting in a right supracondylar humerus fracture. Upon arrival, the patient exhibited a white, cold hand, and the radial pulse was absent. Immediate neurovascular assessment indicated severe ischemia. The orthopedic team was notified, but due to OR schedule constraints, the reduction was delayed until 11:00 AM the next day. During the prolonged wait, the patient developed signs of compartment syndrome, requiring fasciotomy after the delayed reduction. Post-operative assessment revealed persistent motor deficits in the AIN distribution. This case raises concerns about the preventability of the deteriorating neurovascular status.
engine_output.summary: An 8-year-old female sustained a right supracondylar humerus fracture after a bike fall, presenting with severe ischemia and a delayed surgical reduction due to OR schedule constraints, leading to complications including compartment syndrome and persistent motor deficits.

raw_results.scenario_label: AIN palsy documented but summary says 'neurovascularly intact' (Documentation_Gap)

engine_output.raw_input: A 6-year-old boy was evaluated at 08:15 PM after sustaining a left elbow injury while playing. Imaging confirmed a Gartland III supracondylar humerus fracture. The initial exam documented an absent AIN motor function with an 'OK sign' failure, but the discharge summary incorrectly stated that the patient was 'neurovascularly intact.' The surgical intervention was performed at 01:00 AM following a thorough neurovascular assessment, which included radial and ulnar nerve checks. Post-operative notes confirmed the presence of AIN palsy. This discrepancy raises concerns regarding the accuracy of documentation in the patient's records.
engine_output.summary: A 6-year-old boy sustained a Gartland III supracondylar humerus fracture at 08:15 PM, with initial examination revealing absent AIN motor function. Surgery was performed at 01:00 AM, highlighting documentation discrepancies regarding neurovascular status.

raw_results.scenario_label: Brachialis pucker sign requiring unavoidable open reduction (Preventability_Detective)

errors: signals:Missing must_find_signals: open reduction was deemed necessary...

engine_output.raw_input: A 9-year-old female presented at 07:45 PM after a fall from a swing, resulting in a left supracondylar humerus fracture. The orthopedic examination revealed a notable brachialis pucker sign, indicating significant soft tissue compromise. Neurovascular assessment showed a pink, warm hand with intact capillary refill, but the indication for closed reduction was poor due to the pucker sign. An open reduction was deemed necessary and performed at 10:30 PM. Post-operatively, the patient was closely monitored for complications, but the initial assessment raised questions about whether the need for an open reduction could have been prevented with more timely intervention.
engine_output.summary: A 9-year-old female sustained a left supracondylar humerus fracture after a fall at 07:45 PM, with significant soft tissue compromise indicated by a brachialis pucker sign. An open reduction was performed at 10:30 PM, raising concerns about the potential for earlier intervention.

raw_results.scenario_label: Escalating pain and opioids with late compartment syndrome recognition (Safety_Signal + Follow-up stress)

errors: signals:Missing must_find_signals: escalating pain levels over the next few hours, required increasing doses of opioids...

engine_output.raw_input: A 10-year-old male arrived at the emergency department at 11:00 PM after a sports-related injury causing a left supracondylar humerus fracture. Initial neurovascular assessment indicated a pink, warm hand, but the patient reported escalating pain levels over the next few hours, requiring increasing doses of opioids. Despite this, the orthopedic team delayed the surgical intervention until 04:00 AM due to staffing issues. At this time, the patient displayed late signs of compartment syndrome, including severe pain on passive stretch. Immediate fasciotomy was performed, and the case highlights the critical need for timely recognition of compartment syndrome in the context of escalating pain and opioid use.
engine_output.summary: A 10-year-old male presented with a left supracondylar humerus fracture at 11:00 PM, experiencing escalating pain and requiring increasing opioid doses. Surgical intervention was delayed until 04:00 AM due to staffing issues, leading to late signs of compartment syndrome.

raw_results.scenario_label: Delay > 18h due to true lack of NPO status (ate breakfast) (Delay_Driver_Profiler)

errors: signals:Missing must_find_signals: presented to the emergency department at 09:15 AM, Surgery was eventually initiated at 11:00 PM...

engine_output.raw_input: An 8-year-old male presented to the emergency department at 09:15 AM after sustaining a Gartland II supracondylar humerus fracture during a fall from a swing. The patient's mother reported that he had eaten breakfast at 07:30 AM. Initial neurovascular assessment revealed a pink, pulseless hand, and a negative AIN motor exam. Due to the recent intake of food, the patient was not cleared for anesthesia until 02:30 PM. Surgery was eventually initiated at 11:00 PM, resulting in a total delay of 13 hours. The orthopedic team noted no signs of compartment syndrome during the pre-op evaluation, and the patient's pulse was not palpable at the wrist. Overall, the surgical intervention was performed successfully with no immediate complications noted post-operatively.
engine_output.summary: An 8-year-old male sustained a Gartland II supracondylar humerus fracture after a fall from a swing. He experienced a significant delay in surgery due to recent food intake, leading to a total delay of 13 hours before the procedure was initiated at 11:00 PM.

raw_results.scenario_label: Transfer patient from rural hospital with Gartland III, arrived with compartment syndrome signs (Exclusion_Hunter)

errors: signals:Missing must_find_signals: surgical intervention was initiated at 10:30 PM...

engine_output.raw_input: A 10-year-old girl was transferred from a rural hospital to our facility at 03:00 PM after sustaining a Gartland III supracondylar humerus fracture. Upon arrival, she exhibited early signs of compartment syndrome, including severe pain and swelling in the forearm, with a documented pressure of 40 mmHg on compartment measurement. Her neurovascular status was compromised with a white, cold pulseless hand. The orthopedic team rapidly assessed the situation, but due to the significant delay in transfer, definitive surgical intervention was initiated at 10:30 PM. The case was complicated by the initial lack of proper assessment at the rural facility, resulting in a need for urgent fasciotomy.
engine_output.summary: A 10-year-old girl with a Gartland III supracondylar humerus fracture was transferred at 03:00 PM, exhibiting early signs of compartment syndrome and compromised neurovascular status. Definitive surgical intervention was delayed until 10:30 PM due to transfer delays and inadequate initial assessment.

engine_output.raw_input: An 11-year-old female presented to the emergency department at 08:30 AM with a Gartland III supracondylar humerus fracture sustained during a soccer game. Initial examination revealed a pink hand with some sensory deficits, prompting urgent orthopedic consultation. However, due to an overcrowded operating room and multiple emergent cases, her surgery was delayed. The patient remained in the hospital for monitoring until 03:30 AM the next day when she was finally taken to the OR, resulting in a total delay of 19 hours. Throughout her stay, she was monitored for signs of compartment syndrome, which were not evident.

engine_output.raw_input: A 9-year-old boy was brought to the emergency department at 07:45 PM after being involved in a multi-vehicle accident. He sustained a Gartland II supracondylar humerus fracture along with a head injury. Due to the need for neurosurgical evaluation, his definitive fixation was delayed. Neurovascular assessment indicated a pink hand with full pulses but the orthopedic team was unable to proceed with surgery until 01:00 AM the next day after clearance from neurosurgery. Overall, the delay lasted 5 hours before he could undergo surgery, but the orthopedic team noted that this delay was justified given the patient's head injury.
engine_output.summary: A 9-year-old boy sustained a Gartland II supracondylar humerus fracture and a head injury in a multi-vehicle accident. His surgery was delayed for 5 hours due to the need for neurosurgical evaluation, with definitive fixation occurring at 01:00 AM after clearance.
